Interaction Description: Spinach is high in vitamin K which can reduce Warfarin effectiveness and increase the risk of blood clots.
Green tea contains vitamin K which may interfere with Warfarin and reduce its anticoagulant effect.
Grapefruit juice can increase blood levels of Atorvastatin, raising the risk of muscle toxicity.
Grapefruit juice significantly increases Simvastatin levels in the blood, which may cause muscle damage.
Coffee can reduce the absorption of Levothyroxine, decreasing its effectiveness.
High-fiber diets may interfere with the absorption of Levothyroxine.
Calcium in milk binds to Tetracycline, reducing its absorption.
Dairy can decrease absorption of Ciprofloxacin, making it less effective.
Cheese contains tyramine which can interact dangerously with MAOIs, causing hypertensive crisis.
Sodium affects Lithium levels in the blood; sudden changes in salt intake can be dangerous.
Caffeine can reduce the effectiveness of Lithium and increase tremors.
Fiber can bind Digoxin in the gut and reduce its absorption.
Bananas are high in potassium which can lead to hyperkalemia when taken with ACE inhibitors.
Alcohol can cause nausea, cramps, and flushing when taken with Metronidazole.
Alcohol increases the risk of lactic acidosis when taken with Metformin.
High-fat meals can increase Theophylline absorption and toxicity.
Grapefruit juice can delay metabolism of Alprazolam, increasing sedation risk.
Chronic alcohol use may decrease Phenytoin levels; acute use can increase them.
Alcohol increases the risk of GI bleeding when taken with NSAIDs.
Tannins in tea can inhibit iron absorption when taken together.
